into the centre of the country. ⎡As there was no hope ⎡/
of the Boers allowing the peaceable instruction of the
natives at Kolobeng, I at once resolved to save my
family from exposure to this unhealthy region by
sending them to England, and to return alone, with a
view to exploring the country in search of a healthy
district, that might prove a centre of civilization, and
open up the interior by a path to either the east or west
coast. This resolution led me down to ^ the/ Cape Town in
April, 1852, being the first time during eleven years
that I had revisited the scenes of civilization.

To be inserted at bottom of small slip 68*
Our route to Cape Town led us to pass
through the centre of the Colony during
the Twentieth month of a
Caffre War, and if those who
periodically pay enormous
sums for these inglorious
affairs, wish to know how
our little unprotected party
could quietly travel through
the heart of the colony to the
Capital with as little sense
or sign of danger as if we
had been in England
they must engage a "Times
Special
Correspondent" Commissioner" for the next
outbreak to explain where
the money goes, and who
hasve been benefitted by the
p blood and treasure they
expended/ are called upon to spend
⎡Having placed my family on
board a homeward bound
ship and promised to rejoin
them it in two years, we parted
for, ^ as it subsequently proved, nearly five years four and a half - The
Directors of the London
Missionary Society signified
their cordial approval of
my project, by leaving the
matter entirely to my own
judgment and discretion; and
I have much pleasure in
p.93 68* 2
acknowledging my obligations
to the gentlemen then in the
composing
that body direction of the Society infor always
acting in an enlightened spirit
and with as much liberality
as their constitution would
allow

I have the like pleasure
in confessing my thankfulness
to the Astronomer Royal
at the Cape, Thomas Maclear
Esqr-Esquire, for enabling me
to recalrecall the little astronomical
knowledge which constant
manual labour and
the engrossing nature of
missionary duties had effaced
from my memory, and in
adding much that I neverdid not
kneow before - before - The assurance
The promise he made on
parting that he would examine
and correct all my observations
had more effect in making
me persevere in overcoming
the difficulties of an unassisted
solitary observer, than anything
else - so whatever credit
may be attached to the
geographical positions laid
down ^ in my route, must
be attributed to the laborious
voluntary aid of the excellent
and laborious astronomer
of the Cape Observatory -

XXXVI- P358-373 3
Dew. W
pay, and now began to
Set up in
slips - but in
the type of the
Book JM remark that they
must in future fleece
the Mambari as these
Chiboque had done to us;
As they had all been
loud in condemnation
of the mean^ness & &and when
I asked if they could
descend to be equally
mean,- I was answered
that they would only
do it in revenge - They like
to have a plausible excuse for mean^ness -

Next morning our
guides went only about
a mile, and then told
us they would return
home now - I expected
this befwhen paying them
beforehand in accordance with the
entreaties of the Makololo-, who
are rather ignorant of the world
Very energetic remonstrances
were addressed to the guides of
but they slipped off one by
one in the thick forest
through which we were
passing, and I was glad to
hear my companions
coming to the conclusion,
that, as we were now in
parts visited by traders, we
1 did not require the guides;
4
whose chief use had been to prevent
misapprehension of our objects
in the minds of the villagers -
The country was somewhat
more undulating now than it
had been, and several fine
small streams flowed in deep woody
dells The trees of
which are
very tall and
straight and
the forests
gloomy and
damp -; the
ground in
these solitudes
is quite covered
with yellow &
moss brown
mosses, and
bright coloured
lichens clothe
all the trees - - The soil is extremely
fertile, and generally a black
loam covered with a thick
crop of tall grasses - We passed
several villages too - The
headman of a large one scolded
us well for passing when
he intended to give us food -
but wWhere slave-traders have
been in the habit of coming,
they present food, then
demand three or four times
its value as a custom - We
were now rather glad to get
past villages without intercourse
with the inhabitants

We were travelling W- N- W-West North West,
and all the rivulets we here
crossed had a Northerly course,
and were reported to fall into
the Kasai or Loké, ^ Most of them
had the peculiar
boggy banks
of the country/ As we
were now in the alledged
latitudes of the Coanza, I was
much astonished at the
entire absence of any
knowledge of that river
2 expressed by the among the
natives of this quarter,
5
But I was ^ then ignorant of the fact
that the Coanza rises considerably
to the West of this, and has
a comparatively short course
from its source to the sea -
The famous Dr Lacerda
seems to have laboured under
the same mistake as myself,
for he recommended the
Government of Angola to
establish a chain of forts
along the banks of that
river, with a view to
communication with the
opposite coast - As a chain
of forts inalong its course would
lead Southwards instead
of Eastwards, we may infer
that the geographical data
within reach of that eminent
man, were no better than
those according to which
I had directed my course
to the Coanza where it does
not exist

26th We spent Sunday on
the banks of the Quilo or
Kweelo here, a stream of
about ten yards wide.
It, runs in a deep glen,
3 the sides of which are
about five hundred yards
of slope - and rockey - the
rocks being hardened tufa above
clayslate ^ and sandstone below - with
a capping of ferrugineousferruginous conglomerate
6
The scenery would have been very
pleasing, but fever took away
much of the joy of life, and
severe daily intermittents
rendered me very weak
and glad to recline

As we were now in the
slave-market, it struck me
that the sense of insecurity
felt by the natives might
account for the circumstance
that when questioned those
who have been sold as slaves,
and freed again, profess to like
this new state better than
their primitive one,- They
lived on rich fertile plains,
which seldom inspire that
love of country which the
mountains do - If they had
been mountaineers they would
have pined for home - To
one who has observed the
hard toil of the poor in old
civilized countries, the state
in which the inhabitants
here live is one of glorious
ease - WeThe country is full
of little villages - Food abounds
4 and very little labour is
required for its cultivation,
The soil is so rich that
no manure is required;
but when a garden becomes
7
5 too poor for good crops of maize,
beans, &c, the owner removes
a little ^ farther into
the forest,/ - applies fire ^ round to the trees
roots of the larger trees to kill
them,- cuts down the smaller,
and a new rich garden is
ready for the seed. The gardens
usually present the appearance
of a great number of deatall
dead trees standing without
bark, and maize growing
between them - The old gardens
continue to yield manioc
for years after the
owners have removed
to other spots for the sake
of beans and maize - But while
vegetable foodaliment is
abundant, there
is a want of
salt & animal
food,- so that
numberless traps
are ^ seen set for
mice in all the
forests of
Londa - The
vegetable aliment
leaves great
craving for
flesh, and I
have no doubt
but that when
an ordinary
quantity of
mixed food
is supplied to
freed slaves,
they actually do
feel more com/-
fortable than
they did at home -
Their assertions,
however, mean but
little, for they try
to give an answer to please, and if one shewedshowed them
a nugget of gold, they would generally says that they abounded in their country -

One could see the
variety of character inamong
the owners of gardens
and villages - Some were
the pictures of neatness
We entered other villages
enveloped in a wilderness
of weeds so high that
5 when sitting on ox back
in the middle of the
village we could only
see the tops of the huts -
If we entered at midday
the owners would come lazily
forth andpipe in hmouth hand
or leizurelyleisurely puffing away
with in dreamy indifference
8
In other villages weeds are not
allowed to grow;- cotton, tobacco,
and different plants, used
as relishes, are planted round
the huts;- fowls are kept
in cages, and the gardens
present the pleasant spectacle
of different kinds of grain
and pulse at various
periods of their growth -
I sometimes admired this, &
at sometimes the other & wished
I could have taken the world
easy likefor a time like the other -
Every fvillage swarms with
children, who turn out to
see the white man pass, -
and run along with strange
cries and antics;- some
run up trees to get a good
view,- - They are good climbers
throughout Londa - At friendly
villages they have scampered
alongside our party for
miles at a time - We usually
make a little hedge around
6 our sheds ^ cCrowds of women
come to the entrance of this
it with children on their
backs and long pipes
in their mouths, gazing at
us for hours - The men,
rather than disturb them,
crawl through a hole in
the hedge, and it is common
9
to hear a man in running off
say to them "I am going to tell
my Mama to come and see
the white man's oxen"

Powell In continuing our W- N- W-West North West
course we met many parties
of native traders each carrying
some pieces of cloth and salt
with a few beads to barter for
bees wax - they are all
armed with Portuguese guns
and have cartridges with iron
balls. When we meet we
usually stand a few minutes
they present a little salt and
we ^ give a bit
of ox hide
or some
other trifle
and then part with mutual
good wishes - The hide of
the oxen we slaughtered had
been a valuable addition
to our resources for we
found it in so great
repute as girdles all
through Londa that we
cut up every skin into
stripesstrips about two inches
broad and sold them
7 for meal and manioc
as we went along - As
we came nearer Angola
we found them of less
value as the people
there possess cattle themselves

The village on the
Kweelo at which we spent
10
Sunday was that of a civil
lively old man called
Sakandala - who presented
no objection to our progress -
We found we should soon were entering
on the territory of the
Bashinje, (Chinge of the Portuguese)
who are mixed with
Bangala another tribe people named Bangala
which who have been at war
with the Babindele or
Portuguese - Rains and
fever as usual helped to
impede our progress untilluntil
we were put on the
path which leads from
Cassange and Bihe to
Matiamvo - by a head-man
named Kamboela - This
was a well beaten foot-
path and soon after
entering upon it we
met a party of half
cross breed traders from
Bihe who confirmed
the information we
had already got of
8 this path leading
straight through to
Cassange to w through
which they had come
on their way from
Bihe to Cabango - They
kindly presented my
men with some tobacco
11
and marvelled greatly when
they found that I had
never been able to teach
myself to smoke - On parting
with them we came to
a traderstrader's grave - This was
marked by a huge cone
of wood placed in the
form of the roof of a
hut with a pasllisadepalisade
allarround it - At the an
opening on the Western
side an ugly idol was
placed and several
strings of beads and
bits of cloth were
hung around - We learned
that he had been a cross
breed who had died on
his way back from
Matiamvo

As we ^ were now alone
and sure of being on the
way to the abodes of
civilization we went
trtranspose on briskly - We came
oOn the 30th to a sudden
descent from the highland
9 indented by deep narrow
valleys over which
we had lately been
travelling - It is generally
so steep that it can only
be descended at particular
points and even there
12
I was obliged to dismount
though so weak I had to be
led by my companions
to prevent my toppling over
in walking down - It was
annoying to feel myself
so helpless for I never
liked to see a man either
sick or well giving in
effeminately - Below us
lay the valley of the Quango -
If you sit on the spot
where Mary Queen of
Scots viewed the battle
of Langside and look
down on the vale of
Clyde you may see
in miniature the
glorious sight which
a much greater ^ & richer valley
presented to our view
It is ^ about a forest hundred miles broad
covered generally with
dark ^ forest except by where
the broad light green
grass covered meadow
lands on the Quango
which here and there
glances out in the sun
as it wends its way
10to the North – The opposite
side of this great valley
appears like a range
of lofty mountains
and the descent into it
13
about a mile long which
measured perpendicularly
may be abofrom a thousand
to fifteen hun twelve hundred
feet in perpendicular height
Emerging from the
gloomy forest of Londa
this magnificent prospect
made us all feel as
if a weight had been
lifted off our eyelids
A cloud was passing
accross the middle of
the valley from which
rolling thunder pealed while
above all was glorious
sunlight and when we
went down to the part
where we saw it passing
we found that a very
heavy thunder shower had
fallen under the path
of the cloud – and the bottom
of the valley which from
above seemed quite
smooth is we discovered
to be intersected & furrowed
by great numbers of
deep cut streams – Looking
back from below
11 The descent appears as
the edge of a table land
with numerous indented
dells and spurs are jutting
14
out all along giving it a
serrated appearance - Both
top & sides of the sierra
are covered with trees
but large patches of the
more perpendicular parts
are bare and exhibit
the red soil which is
general over the region
we have now entered

This hollow affords a
section of the part of the
country and we find that
the uppermost stratum is
the ferruginiousferruginous conglomerate
The matrix is rust of iron
and in it are embedded water
worn pebbles of sandstone
and quartz - As this is
the rock underlying the
soil of a large part of
Londa its formation
must have preceded the
work of denudation
which hol washed away
the enormous mass
of matter required before
the valley of Cassange
12 could assume its
present form - The
strata under the conglomerate
are all of red clay slate
of different degrees of
hardness the moset
15
indurated being at the bottom -
The red clay slate is named
Keele in Scotland and has
always been considered
as an indication of gold -
but the only thing we dis-
-covered was it cannot
it had given rise to a very
slippery clay soil veryso different
from that which we
had just left that several
Mashauana who always
prided himself on being
an adept at balancing
himself in the canoe on
water and so sure of foot
on land that he could afford
to express contempt for
anyone less gifted, came
down in a very sudden
and undigniffied manner
to the delight of all whom
he had previously scolded
for falling -

Here we met with the
13 Bamboos as thick as a
man's arm - and many
new trees - others which
we had lost sight of
Shinte's since leaving Shinte's
now reappeared - but
nothing struck us more
than the comparative
scragginess of the trees
in this hollow - Those
16
on the high lands we had
left were tall and straight
here they were stunted and
not by any means so
closely planted together - The
only way I could account
for itthsthis was by supposing
as the trees were different
species ^ that the greater altitude suited
the nature of those above
thanbetter than the lower
14 altitude did the other species
below -

Mead Sunday 2d April - We rested beside
a small stream where we
slaughtered the last spare and
our hunger being now very
severe from having
lived on
manioc ^ alone, since
leaving Ionga
Panza's - we/ slaughtered one of
our four remaining oxen The people of
this district
seem to feel
the craving for
animal food
as much as we
did for they
spend much
energy in digging
large white
larvae out of
the damps
soil adjacent
to their streams/
and use them as a relish for their vegetable diet
The Bashinjé refused to
sell any food for the
poor old ornaments
my men had now to offer
We could get neither meal
nor manioc but would
have been comfortable had
not the Bashinje chief
Sansáwé pestered us for the
customary present - The
native traders informed
us that a display of force
was often necessary
before they could pass
this man - so we

Sansawe the chifef of a
portion of the Bashinje shaving
sent the usual formal
demand ofor a man an ox
or a tusk and spoke very
contemptuously of the poor
things we offered him
instead - We shewedshowed his
messengers people that we had nothing
else to offer - Everything
was gone except my
instruments which could
be of no use to them whatever
One of them begged some
meat and when it was
refused said to my men
you may as well give it
for we shall take it all
after when we have killed you
tomorrow - The more humbly
we spoke the more insolent
the Bashinje became, till
at last we were all
feeling savage and sulky
In the evening we
were visited by Sansawe
15 him but continued to speak
as civilly as we could
They are fond of argument
and when we den I denied
their right to demand tribute
from a white man who
did not trade in slaves
an old white headed negro
18
put rather a posing question
"You know that God has
placed chiefs amongs us
whom we ought to honour
and support, you say
that you who have a book
which tells you his will
hHow is it that you
who have a book that tells
you about him do not
come forward at once
to pay this chief tribute
like every one else? I
replied by asking "How
could I know that this
was a chief - who had
allowed me to remain
a day & a half near him
without giving me anything
to eat - ?" This which
to the unintiitiated may
seem sophistry iswas to thes
central Africans quite
a rational question for
274 he at once addmitted
that [food ought to have
been sent and added that
16 probably his chief was
only making it ready
for me and that it
would soon come

After being wearied
by talking all day
wito different parties sent
19
by Sansawe we were honoured
by a visit from himself
WHe is quite a young man
and of rather a pleasing
countenance - There cannot
have been much intercourse
between real Portuguese
and these people even here
so close to the Quango for
Sansawe asked me to
shewshow him my hair ason
the ground that though
he had heard of it and
some had even passed
through his country he
had never seen it
straight hair before - This
is quite possible as
most of the slave
traders are not Portuguese
but cross-breeds - , The
difference between their
wool and our hair
caused him to burst into
a laughs and the contrast
between the exposed
17 and unexposed parts
of my skin seem to
strike him when
exhibited in evidence
of our all being made
of one stock originally
& were all the children
of one Maker seemed
20
to strike him andwith awe,
wonder, I then shewedshowed him
my watch and wished to
win my way into his
confidence by conversation
but when about to
exhibit my pocket compass
he desired me to desist
as he was afraid of my
wonderful things - I told
him if he had known
mey ^ aims as / the tribes in the
Interior had done did and
x as I hoped he would yet
know methem & me he
would have been glad to
stay & to see evenalso the pictures
of the Magic Lantern - but
as it was now getting
dark he had evidently
got enough of my witchery
and began to use some
charms to dispel any
kindly feelings he may
have felt stealing round
his heart - He asked leave
to go and when his
18 party moved off a little
way he sent for my
head spokesman spokesman
and told him that "if
Iwe did not add a red jacket
and a man to our gift
of a few copper rings &
a few pounds of meat"
21
I observed my companions
remark in their own tongue in answer to
threats of attack with clenched
teeth "that's what we want"
"only begin then" - or with
clenched teeth they would
exclaim to each other
"these slaves things have never
travelled and do not know
what men are" - The
worrying of which I give
only a slight sketch had
considerable influence
on my own mind - The
more especially as it
was impossible now
to make any allowance
for the Bashinje such
as we I was willing
to award to the Chiboque
They saw ^ that we had nothing
to give nor would they
be benefitted in the least
by enforcing the impudent
order to return whence
we had come - They were
adding insult to injury
and this put us all
20 into a fighting spirit which
as far as and as nearly
as we could judge we
expected to be obliged to
cut our way through the
Bashinje next morning.

The Quango is said ^ by the natives to con-
-tain many venomous 22
water snakes which
congregate near the
carcase of any hippopotamus
that may be killed in
it - If this is true it
will account for all
the villages we saw
being situated far from
its banks - We were
advised to not to sleep
near it but as we were
anxious to cross to
the W^w/estern side we tried
to induce some of the
Bashinje to lend us
canoes for the purpose
This brought out the chief
of these parts who informed
us that all the canoe men
were his children and nothing
could be done without
hims authority - He then
made the ^usual demand for a
man, ^ an ox, or a gun adding
that without otherwise
one of ^ these we
must return to the country
from which we had
come - As I did not believe
this man had any power
23 over the canoes of the
other side and suspected
that if I gave him my
23
blanket the only thing I now
had in reserve - he might
leave us in the lurch after
all - I tried to persuade my
men to go at once to the
banks about two
miles off and have obtain
possession of the canoes
before we gave up the
blanket but they thought
that he mig this chief
might attack us in
the act of crossing
should we do so if we did so - The chief
came himself to our
encampment and made
his demand again - My
men stripped off the last
of their copper rings
and gave them - but
he was still intent on a
man - He thought as
others did that my
men were slaves - He
was a young man with
his wooly hair elaborately
dressed - That behind was
24 made up into a cone about
eight inches in diameter
at the base - carefully wound
swathed round with red and black
thread - As I resisted the
proposal to deliver up my
blanket untilluntil I had they had
placed us on the W^w/.estern
bank this chief continued
24
to worry us with his demands
till I was tired but my
little tent ^ was now in tatters
and having a wider hole
behind than the door in front
I in vain I tried to
lie down out of sight of
our persecutors - We
were on a reedy flat
and I could not follow
our/. our my usual plan of a
small stockade in which where
we had time to think
& concoct our plans
As I was trying to persuade
my men to move on
in spite of these people to
the bank a young half
breed blood Portuguese sergeant
of militia, Cypriano di
Abreu made his appearance
and gave the same advice
He had come across the
Quango in search of bees-
wax and assisted us in
making our arrangement
25 with the ferryman without
parting with my blanket

When we moved off
from thise chief who had
been plaguing us his people
opened a fire against
from ^ our sheds and continued
to blaze away some time
in the our direction we were
going
25
but none of the bullets reached
us - It is probable that they
expected the demonstration
of the abundance of ammunition
they possessed would
make us run but when
we continued to move
quietly to the ford they
proceeded no farther
than our sleeping place.

Cypriano assisted us
in making a more satisfactory
arrangement with the ferrymen
than parting with my
blanket and as soon
as we reached the opposite
Bangala bank we were in the
territory of the Bangala
who are subjects of
the Portuguese and often
spoken of as
the Cassanges
or Cassantse and happily
all our difficulties with
the border tribes were
at an end -

Passing with light
hearts alothrough the high
grass forby a narrow
footpath for about three
miles to the wWest of the
26 river we came to several
neat square houses
and many cleanly looking
haf cross breaed Portuguese
standing in front of tothem
to salute us - They are all
26
enrolled in the Militia and
our friend Cypriano is
the commander of a
division established here -
The Bangala were very
troublesome to the Portuguese
traders and at last pro-
-ceeded so far as to kill
one of them when the
Government of Angola
at last sent an expedition
against them - which
being successful the
Bangala were dispersed
and are now returning
to their former abodes
The militia are settled
over them and engage
in trade and cultivation ^ agriculture/
for their support as no
pay is given to this
branch of the service
by the Government

We came to the dwelling
of Cypriano after it was
dark and I pitched my
little tent in front of it
27 for the night - We had
the company of mosquitoes
here though they do not
We never found them
troublesome on the
banks of the pure streams
of LŏndaLonda - On the morning
27
a small cyclopaedia and a
Portuguese dictionary - in which
the definition of a "Priest"
seemed ^ sounded ^ rather strange to a Protestant
vizvidelicet - "one who takes care of the
conscience" - They had also
a few tracts containing the
lives of the saints and Cypriano
had a few small images
of saints in wax in his room
One of these was St Ant^honySt Anthony
and a who had he endured
the privations he did in
his cell in looking after
these lost sheep would
have lived to better purpose
Neither Cypriano nor
his companions knew
what the bBible was but they had
relics in germanGerman
silver cases hung
round their necks
to act as charms
& save them from
danger by land or
by water in the
same way the

of forest and meadow like

a tribe living in subjection
to the Portuguese - We crossed
several little streams
which were flowing
in the Westerly direction
in which we were marching
to fand unite to form
Quize the Quize a feeder of the
Coanza Coanza - The Basongo
were very civil as
indeed all the tribes
awere who haved been
conquered by the Portuguese,
The Basongo and Bangala
are ^ yet only partially subdued
The farther west we go
go from this we
find the black population
less independantindependent untilluntil
we reach the confines
vicinity of LoandaLuanda where
the free natives ^ they are nearly identical
in their feelings towards the Government with the slaves
14 57
But the Govern^orsment of
Angola wisely accepts the
limited allegiance and
tribute rendered by the
more distant tribes as better
than none -

All the inhabitants of
this region as well as
those of Londa may be
called true negroes if the
limitations formerly made
be borne in mind - The
dark colour, thick lips ^ flat, heads
elongated backwards and
upwards and covered with
wool flat noses and with other negro
peculiarities are general
but while these characteristics
place them in the true negro
family, the reader would
imbibe a wrong idea did
if he supposed that all
these features ^ combined are often met
with in one individual
Thus All arehave
a certain
thickness
& prominence
of lips but, , many are met with
in every village in whom
thickness and projection
of lips is nare not more
marked than in some
Europeans - All are dark
but that colour is shaded
off in different individuals
from deep black to light
yellow - As we go Westwards
15 58
we observe the light colour
predominating over the dark
and then again when we
come within the influence
of damp from the sea
air, we find the shade
deepen again into the
general blackness of
the coast population,
The shape of the head with
its wooly crop though
general is not universal
The Caffre head The tribes
on the Eastern side of the
continent as the Caffres
have heads finely
developed and strongly
European - Instances of
this kind are so numerous
frequently seen and I have
after I became so
familiar with the dark
colour as to forget it
in viewing the countenance
I have been struck by
the strong resemblances
some personsnatives bore
to certain of our own
notabilities - The Bushmen
and Hottentots are exceptions
to these remarks for both
the shape of their heads
and growth of wool
are peculiar - The latter
16 59
for instance frsprings from
the scalp in tufts with
bare spaces between and
when the crop is short
resembles a number of
black peppercorns stuck on the
skin - head, and very unlike
the thick frizzly masses
ofwhich cover the heads
of the Balonda and Maravi
With every disposition
to pay due deference to
the opinions of those
who have made Ethnology
their special study I
have felt myself unable
to believe that the
exaggerated features usually
put forth as those of
the typical negro characterize
any nation of south
central Africa - The
monuments of ^ the Ancient
Egyptians seem to me
to embody the ideal
of the inhabitants of
Londa better than the
figures of any work
of Ethnology I have met
with -

p.del:
Sunday 30th We spent at Ngio
(pronounced Njeeo)

div.p:
Passing through ^ the same fine
fertile and well peopled
Sanza country to Sanza we found
the Quize again touching
our path and here
we had the pleasure of
seeing a field of wheat
growing luxuriantly without
irrigation - The ears were
upwards of ^ four inches long and
were an object of great
curiosity to my companions
because they had tasted
my bread at Linyanti
but had never before
seen wheat growing.
This small field was
cultivated by Mr Miland
an agreableagreeable Portuguese
gmerchant - His garden
was interesting as shewingshowing
what the land at this
elevation is capable of
abyielding for besides
wheat he had we
saw European vegetables
in a flourishing condition
and we afterwards discovered
that the coffee plant has
propagated itself oneon certain
spots parts of this same district
And It may be seen
18 61
on the heights of Tala MungongaTala Mungongo
or nearly 300 miles from
the West coast where it was
first introduced by the
Jesuit missionaries -

We spent Sunday 30th
April at Ngio (soft g) Njeeo)
close to the ford of the Quize
The country becomes more
open ^ but is still abundantly
fertile with a
thick crop
of grass
about
between two
and three
feet high
It is also and well wooded
and watered - Villages of
Basongo are dotted over
the country ^ landscape and frequently
a square houses of
wattle and daub belonging
to a native Portuguese
are placed beside them
for the purpose of trade
The people here possess
both cattle and pigs - The
different sleeping places
on our path arefrom
eight to ten miles apart
are marked by a cluster
of sheds made of sticks
and grass - There is
a constant stream
of people going and
returning to & from
the coast - The goods are
carried on the head or
on one shoulder in a
sort of basket having
planted between attached to at the extremities of two poles
19 61a
stet between five to and six feet ^ in length long
& called Motete - When the basket is placed on
the head, the poles project
forwards horizontally and
when the carrier wishes
to rest himself he places
th plants them on the ground
& the burden against a tree
so he is they are not obliged to lift
it up from the ground to the
level of the head - It stands
against the tree propped up
by the poles at that level -
The carrier They frequently plants the
poles on the ground &
stands holding the burden
untilluntil they have ^ he has taken
breath thus avoiding the
trouble of placing the
burden on the ground &
lifting it up again

When a company of these
carriers or our own
party ^ company comes to one
of these sleeping places
immediate possession
is taken of the sheds
Those who come late
and find all the hoccupied
must then erect others
for themselves - but
this is not difficult
for there is no lack
of long grass - No sooner
20 62
do the ^ any strangers appear at the
spot than the women may
be seen emerging from
their villages bearing
baskets of manioc meal
roots ^ earth-nuts, yams - birdsbird's eye
pepper and garlic for sale,
Calico of which we had
brought some from
Cassange is the chief
medium of exchange
We found them all civil
& though it was evident
from the amount of
talking and laughing in
bargaining that the ladies
enjoyed their occupation
They must cultivate
largely in order to be
able to supply the constant
succession of strangers
Those ^ however near to the great
line of road purchase
also ^ much of the food
also from the more
distant villages for the
sake of gain -

Pitsane and another of
the men had violent attacks
ofor fever, and it was no
wonder for the dampfness
& evaporation from of the ground was excessive
When at any time I attempted
to get an observation
of a star, if the trough

It would have afforded me
pleasure to have cultivated
a more intimate acquaintance
with the inhabitants of
this part of the country
but the giddiness vertigo produced
by ^ by my frequent fevers
made me it as much
as I could do to stick to
the ox and crawl along
in misery - In crossing
Lombe the Lombe my ox Sinbad
in the indulgence of his
propensity to strike out
a new path for himself
plunged into a deep hole
overhead and so wetted
soused me my clothing that I was
obliged to move on
to and dry my thclothing
without waiting on
the ^ Europeans Portuguese ^ who live
on the bank ^ there - But we passed
This I regretted for all the
Portuguese were very
kind and like the Boers
placed in similar
circumstances feel
it ^ a slight to be passed
without a word of
salutation, But we
passed on to a spot
where orange trees
had been planted by the
natives themselves
24 64
and where abundance of that
refreshing fruit was exposed
for sale -

In entering the district of
Ambaca Ambaca we found the
landscape enlivened by the
appearance of lofty mountains
in the distance - The grass
comparatively short and
the whole ^ country landscape at this
time looked graay gray and verdant - On
our leftright we seeaw the certain
Pungo Andongo rocks ^ of the same nature with those of Pungo Andongo
& which closely resemble those
the group
of Stonehenge The Stonehenge
group on Salisbury Plains only
here have the stone pillars ^ here are of
gigantic size - This district
isregion is all wonderfully fertile
and famed for rearing
cattle and all kinds of agricultural
produce at a cheap
rate - The soil contains
sufficient ferrugineous
matter to impart a red tinge
to nearly the whole of it - It
is from supplied with a
great number of little flowing
streams which unitieng
in the Lucalla - This little
river drains Ambaca then
falls into the Coanza into the
South East at Massangano
We crossed the Lucalla by
means of a large canoe
25 65
kept here by a man who
farms the ferry from the
Government and charges
about a penny per head -
A few miles beyond the
Lucalla we came to
the village of Ambaca an
important place in former
times but now a mere
paltry village on a
beautiful
situation
^ at on a little
elevation
^ in on a plain
surrounded
on haall hands
by lofty
mountains without either
church or fort It has a
jail and a good house
for the commandant
but neither fort nor
church - The signs of
a church though the ruins
of a former place of worship
are still standing

We were most kindly
recievedreceived by the Commandant
of Ambaca Arsenio P. P. de Carpo
who spoke a little English &
He recommended wine for
my debility and here I took
the first glass of that beverage
I had taken in Africa I felt much
refreshed
and could
then realize
& meditate on
the The
eff^ weakening effects of the
fever which ^ They were curious
even to myself for though
I had tried several times
since we left Ngio to
take aLunar observations
I could not avoid confusion
of time and distance - I could
26 66
nor could I hold the instrument steady nor
perform a simple calculation
hence many of the portions
onf this part of the route
were left till my return
from LoandaLuanda often on
getting up
in the
mornings I
found my
clothing as
wet from
perspiration as
if theyit had been
dipped in water - In vain had
I tried to ^ learn or collect words of
the Bunda or dialect spoken
in Angola - I forgot the days
of the week and the names
of my companions and
had I been asked I probably
could not have told my own -
The complaint itself occupied
many of my thoughts - One day
day I I supposed that thought I had got the true
theory of it and would certainly
cure themy next attack whether
in myself or companions
but some new symptoms
would appear and scatter
all mythe fine speculations
which had sprung up
with extraordinary fertility
in one department of my
brain

This district is said to
contain upwards of 40,000
souls - Some ten or twelve
miles to the North of the village
of Ambaca there once
stood the missionary
station of Cahenda and
it is now quite astonishing
27 67
to observe the great numbers
who can read and write in
theis district - Theis is the fruit
of the labours of the Jesuits
ofor they taught the people
of Ambaca usually termed
Ambacistas and ever since
the expulsion of the teachers
by the Marquis of Pombal
Theythe ^ natives have continued to teach
each other - These devoted
men are held in high estimation
throughout this country to this
day - All speak well of them
(os padres Jesuitas) and now
that they are gone from this
lower sphere I could not
help wishing that ^ these our Roman
Catholic fellow Christians
had felt it to be their duty
to give their people the
Bible to be a light to their
feet when the good men
themselves were gone -

When sleeping in the house
of the Commandant an insect
well known in this country
by the name Tampan bit
my foot - It is a kind of
tick and chooses by preference
the parts between the fingers
and toes for inflicting its bite
Its is often seen of from
28 68
the size of a pin's head to that of
a pea and inis common
in all the native huts in
this country - It sucks the
blood untilluntil quite full and
it is then of dark blue
colour and its skin so
tough and yielding that it
is impossible to burst it
by any amount of slqueezing
by the fingers - I had
felt itsthe effects of is bite
in former years and
eschewed all native huts
ever after but as I was
here again assailed in a
native European house
I shall detail the effects
of the bite - These are a
tingling sensation of mingled
pain and itchiness which
commences ascending
the limb untilluntil the poison
imbibed reaches the
abdomen where it soon
causes violent vomiting
and purging - Where these
effects do not follow
as we found afterwards
at Tete fever sets in
and I was assured by
intelligent Portuguese there
that death fby this fever
has ^ sometimes been the result of this fever - From
2930 69
conversation I found on
rising from a dasedaze his
couch - that he had at once
proceeded to cook a fowl
for my use and at
parting he pressed me to
a glass of wine which
prevented a violent fit
of shivering which I expected
that afternoon - The
universal hospitality of the
Portuguese was most
gratifying as it was quite
unexpected - And even
now as I copy my
journal I remember it
all with a glow of
gratitude

We spent Sunday 14th
May at Cabinda Cabinda which
is one of the stations
of the subcommandants
who which are placed at
different points in each
district of Angola for as
assistants of the head-
commandant or Chefe
It is situated in a beautiful
glen and surrounded
by plantations of bananas
and manioc - The
country was daily gradually
becoming more picturesque
31 70
the farther we proceeded West
the ranges of lofty blue
mountains of Libollo which in coming
towards Ambaca we had
seen thirty or forty miles
to our South were now
shut out from our
view by others nearer
at hand and the grey
ranges of Cahenda which
while we inwere in Ambaca stood
clearly defined eight or ten
miles off to the North
were now close upon
our right - As we looked
back towards the open
pastoral
country of Ambaca
Thethe broad green pgently
undulating pastoral plains
seemed in a hollow
surrounded on all sides
by distant rugged mountains and
as we we went West-
wards ^ we were entering upon
quite a wild ^ looking mountainous
district called Golungo
Alto Golungo
Alto We met numbers of
Mambari on their way
Bihe someback to Bihe - Some
of them had belonged to
the parties which had
penetrated as far as
Linyanti and foolishly
shewedshowed their displeasure
at the prospect of the
32 71
Makololo preferring to go to
the coast markets themselves
to entrusting them with their
ivory - They ^ Mambari repeated the
tale of the mode in which
the white men are said to
trade - "The ivory is placed
on the shore in the evening
and next morning the
vender seller finds a quantity
of goods placed there in
its stead - They added to
my men by the white men
who live in the sea" - "Now"
added they to my men
"how can you Makololo
trade with these "Mermen" Can
you enter into the sea &
tell them to come and
ashore - " It was remarkable
to hear this stidea repeated
so near the sea as we
now were - My men
replied that they only
wanted to see for them-
-selves and as they were
now getting some light
on the nature of the trade
carried on by the Mambari
they were highly amused
on percievingperceiving to see the reasons why
the Mambari would rather
have met them on the
ZambesiZambezi than so near
the sea coast
34 72
keep their families out of the
reach of the malaria which
is supposesupposed to prevail most
Sowels on the banks of the numerous
little streams which run
among the hills -

Canto e Castro We were most kindly
recievedreceived by the Commandant
Lieutenant Antonio do Canto e Castro a
young gentleman whose whole sub-
sequent conduct inspired
m will ever make me
regard him with great
affection - Like all every
other person of intelligence
whom I had met he
lamented deeply the apathy
neglect ^ with which this fine
country hasd been treated -
This district contains a population
which numbered according
inhabitants
which counted
by ^ to the last census ^ was 26,000 hearths
or fires - And if to each
hearth we considerreckon three
or four souls we have a
population of upwards of
1064,000 90,000 - The number
of ^ Carregadores (carriers)^ whose services
may be called for ^ by the commandant several
times a year is 6000
who may be ordered out
at the pleasure of Government
to convey merchandise to
the coast is in this district
alone about six thousand
35 73
yet there is no good road
in existence - This system
of compulsory carriage of
merchandise was adopted
in consequence of the increased
activity of the cruizerscruizers
in suppressing the slave trade
which began in 1845
in numbers and activity
of the ^ our cruizerscruizers which took
place in 1845 Each trader
in the purwho went previous to
that year previous to this into the
Interior in the pursuit of
his calling, proceeded on
the plan of purchasing
ivory & beesbees' wax and a
sufficient number ^ of slaves to carry all he got
these commodities - The whole were intended
for exportation as soon
as the trader reached the
coast. But when the
more stringent measures
of 1845 came into operation
and rendered the easy
exportation of slaves
almost impossible, bthere
being no roads proper
for the employment
of wheel conveyances - this
new system of compulsory
carriage of ivory and
bees waxbeeswax to the coast
was resorted to by the
Government of LoandaLuanda
36 74
A trader who now requires
two or three hundred carriers
to convey his merchandise to
the coast now applies to the
General Government, for
aid - An order is sent to
the commandants of
a the districts to furnish the
number required - Each
headman of the villages
under him to whom the
order is ^ transmitted the order must
furnish from five to
twenty or thirty men
according to the proportion
that his people bear to
the entire population of
the district - For this accom-
modation the ptrader must
pay a tax to the Government
of 1000 reis or about three
shillings per load carried
Each carrier recievesreceives
The trader is obliged alsto pay
the carrier also, the sum of 50 reis
or about two pence a day
for his sustenance - And
as tha day's journey is never
more than from eight
to ten miles the expense
which must be incurred
by for the compulsory labour
is felt to be considerable
by those who hwere accustomed
to employ slave labour alone

38 75
custard apples and Pitangas
Jambos a fruits brought from
South America by the former
missionaries - The towering
high hills all around with palms
on many points made
this spot appear more
like the Bay of Rio de
Janeiro in miniature
than any scene I ever
saw, and all who
have seen that confess
that it is unequalled in
the world beside - The fertility
evident in every spot
of this district iswas quite
marvellous to behold
but I shall reserve further
notices of this region
till our return from
LoandaLuanda

We left Golungo Alto on
the 24th of May - the winter
in these parts - Every evening
clouds come rolling in
great masses over the
mountains in the West
and rolling thunder accompanies
the fall of rain during
the night or early in
the morning - The clouds
generally remain on the
hills till the morning
is well spent - so that
39 76
we become familiar with
morning mists, a thing we
never once saw at
Kolobeng - The thermometer
stands at 80° by day but
sinks as low as 76° by
night

In going westwards we
crossed several fine little
gushing streams which
never dry - They unite in
the Luinha (pronounced
Lueenya) and Lucalla - As
they flow through liover
many little cascades
they might easily be turned
to good account but
they are all allowed to
run on idly to the ocean -
We passed through forests
of gigantic timber and
at an open space named
Cambondo about eight
miles from Golungo Alto
found numbers of carpenters
converting these lofty
trees into planks in
exactly the same manner
as was followed by
the illustrious Robinson
CruzoeCrusoe - A tree of three
or four feet in diameter
was felle and forty or
fifty feet up to the nearest
branches was felled -
40 77
It was then cut into lengths
of ofa few feet and split into
thick junks - which again
were rejduced to planks
an inch thick by persevering
labour with the axe -
The object of the carpenters
was to make little chests
and they drive a constant
trade in them at Cambondo
When finished with hinges
lock and key all of their
own manufacture they
one costs only one ^ a shilling and
eight pence - My men were
so delighted with them
that they carried several
of them on their heads
all the way to Linyanti -

At Trombeta we were
pleased to observe a great
deal of taste displayed by the sub-
commandant in the
laying out of his grounds
and adornment of his
house with flowers -
This trifling incident
was the more pleasing
as it was the first
attempt at neatness I had
seen since leaving the
establishment of Mozinkua
in Londa - Rows of
41 78
Powell of trees had been planted along
each side of the road
290 with pine applespineapples and
flowers between - This
[ arrangement I had an opportunity of
seeing in several other
districts of this country
for there is no difficulty
in raising any
plant or tree if it
is only kept from being
cloaked by weeds

This gentleman had now
a fine estate which
but a few years ago
was a forest and
cost him only £16 - He
had planted about 900
coffee trees upon it and
as these begin to yield
in three years from
being planted and in
six attain their maximum
the eI have no doubt but
that ere now his £16
yields him sixty fold
All sorts of fruit trees
and grape vines here yield their fruit twice
in each year without
any labour or irrigation
being bestowed on them
All grains ˄ & vegetables if only sown
do the same and beans
if advantage is taken of
of the fmists of winter even
42 79
even three crops ˄ of pulse may be
Cotton was now standing
in the pods in his fields
and he did not seem to
care about it - I understood
him to say that this last
plant flourishes but the
wet of one of the two
rainy seasons with which
this country is favoured
sometimes proves
troublesome to the grower
I am not aware whether
wheat has ever been
tried but I saw both
figs and grapes in bearing
well - The great complaint
of all cultivators is the
want of a good road
to carry their produce
to market - Here all kinds
of food are remarkably
cheap

Fathrther on we left
the mountainous country
and as we descended towards
the West coast saw the
lands assuming a more
sterile uninviting aspect
On our left right ran
the river Senza which
nearer the sea takes the
name of Bengo - It is
about fifty yards broad
43 80
and navigable for canoes
The low plains adjacent to
its banks are protected from
inundation by embankments
and the population is entirely
occupied in raising
food and fruits for export-
ation to LoandaLuanda by
means of canoes - The banks
are infested by myriads of
the most ferocious mosquitoes
I ever met - Not one of
our party could get a
snatch of sleep - I was taken
into the house of a Portuguese
but was soon glad to make
my escape and lie across
the path on the leeside of
the fire where the smoke
blew over my body - My
host wondered at my
want of taste and I at
his want of feeling for
to our astonishment he
and the other inhabitants
had actually become used
to what was at least equal
to a nail through the heel
of one's boot or the
toothache -

As we were now drawing
near to the sea my companions
were looking at everything
in a serious light - One
of them asked me if -

XLI - P.406-425 81
purpose of navigation but their vessels were so
frequently plundered by their Dutch neighbours that
when they regained the good port of LoandaLuanda they no longer
made use of the river. We remained here
four days in hopes of obtaining an observation for
the longitude but at this season of the year the sky
is almost constantly overcast by a thick canopy
of clouds of a milk and water hue this continues
until the rainy season ^ which was now close at hand commences.

The lands on the north side of the Coanza belong to
the Quisamas (Kisamas) an independent tribe
which the Portuguese have not been able to subdue
The few who came under my observation possessed
? a little of the Bushman ofor HotentotHottentot feature and
were dressed in strips of bark hanging from the waist
to the knee. They deal largely in salt which their
country produces in great abundance. It is brought
in crystals of about 12 inches long and about 1½1/2 inch
in diameter This is met withhawked about everywhere in
Angola and next to calico is the most common
medium of barter The Kisama are brave and
when the Portuguese army pur followed them into
their forests they soon reduced the invaders to
extremity by tapping all the reservoirs of water
which were no other than the enormous Baobabs
of the country hollowed into cisterns . As the Kisama Country
is ill supplied with water otherwise, the Portuguese
were soon obliged to retreat. Their Country
near to Massangano is low lying and marshy
but becomes more elevated in the distance
and beyond them lie the ^ d lofty dark ^ mountain ranges of
mountains of the Libollo another powerful
& independent people Near Massangano
I observed what seemed to be an effort of nature
82
to furnish a variety of domestic fowls more
? capable than the common of bearing the heat of the
sun This was a hen and chickens with all
their feathers curled upwards They were thus
capable of giving shade to the body without increasing the heat
They are here named "Kisafu" by the native population
who pay a high prizce price for them when they wish to offer
them as a sacrifice and by the Portuguese ^ they are termed "Arripiada"
or shivering There seems ^ to be a tendency inin nature
to afford varieties bradapted to the convenience of man

There is a kind of very short legged fowls among
? the Boers obtained in consequence of observing that short
such limbed fr ones were more easily caught for transport
in their frequent removals in search of pasture
A similar instance of securing a variety, occurred
with the short legged ^ limbed sheep in America

Returning by way of ^ ascending the Lucalla
into Cazengo we had an opportunity of visiting
several flourishing coffee plantations and
observed that men several men who had begun
with no capital but honest industry had
in the course of a few years acquired a comfortable ^ subsistence
competency One of these Mr Pinto ^ Pinto fairly generously
furnished me with a
a good supply of his excellent
coffee and my men
with a breed of rabbits
to carry to their own
country Their coffee lands granted
by GovtGovernment yielded without much labour
coffee sufficient for all the necessaries of life

The fact of other avenues of wealth opening
? up so readily, seems like an providential invitatinvitation
to forsake the slave trade and engage in lawful
commerce. We saw the female population
employed ^ occupied as usual in the spinning of cotton and
cultivation of their lands ^ Their only instrument
for culture is a
double handled hoe
which is held in both
hands & worked with
a sort of dragging
motion and manyMany of the men
were employed in weaving The latter appear
to be less industrious than the former for they require
a month to finish a single web. There is

p.add:
however not much inducement to industry
for notwithstanding the time consumed in its manu-
facture each web only bring is sold for only 2 shillings

div.p:
On returniging to Golungo
Alto I found several of my
men laid up ofwith fever -
One of the reasons for my
leaving them there was
that they might recover
from the fatigue of the journey
from LoandaLuanda which may
had much more effect
upon their feet than
hundreds of miles had

Another effort has been made to attract
commercial enterprise into this region by offering
permission to any mining company, willing to
search for the ores and work them, to do so.
Such a company, however, would gain but little
in the way of protection from the government of
Mozambique, for it can itself but barely
maintain a hold on its own small possessions,
and the conditions affixed of importing at its
Thethe company's ^ own cost a certain number of Portuguese from
the island of Madeira or the Azores by way
of increasing the Portuguese populations in Africa
is impolitic. Taxes would also be levied on the
minerals exported by the company. It is
noticeable that all the companies that have been
proposed in Portugal have this put prominently
in the preamble "And for the abolition of the
inhuman slave trade." This shows, either
that the statesmen in Portugal are enlightened
and philanthropic, or it may be meant as a
trap for English capitalists, I incline to
believe the former. But if the Portuguese
really wish to develop the resources of the
rich country beyond their possessions, they
ought to invite the cooperation of other
nations on equal terms with themselves. Let
the pathway into the interior be free to all;
and instead of wretched forts with scarcely
an acre of land around them which they
can call their own, let real colonies be
made. If instead of military establishments
we had civil ones, and saw emigrants going
out with their wives, ploughs, and seeds, rather
than military convicts with bugles and
2 201
kettle drums, we might hope for a return of
prosperity to Eastern Africa.

The village of SennaSena stands on the right
bank of the ZambesiZambezi. There are many reedy
islands in front of it, and there is much bush
in the country adjacent. The soil is fertile,
but the village, being in a state of ruin, and
having several pools of stagnant water, is
very unhealthy. The bottom rock is the akosearkose
of BrogniartBrongniart, or granitic grit, and several
conical hills of trap have burst through it.
One standing about half a mile west of the
village is called Baramuauna, which has
another behind it, hence the name, which means
"carry a child on the back". It is 300 or 400
feet high, and on the top lie two dismounted
cannon which were used to frighten away
the Landeens, who in one attack upon SennaSena
killed 150 of the inhabitants. The prospect from
Baramuau^na is very fine, Below on the
eastward lies the ZambesiZambezi with the village
of SennaSena, and some twenty or thirty miles
Morumbála beyond stands the lofty mountain Morumbala
probably 3000 or 4000 feet high. It is of an
oblong shape and from its physiognomy
which can be distinctly seen when the sun
is in the West, is evidently igneous. On At
the northern end there is a hot sulphurous
fountain which my Portuguese friends refused
? to allow me to visit, because it ^ the mountain is well peopled
and the inhabitantsmountaineers are at present not
friendly with the Portuguese. They have
plenty of garden ground and running water
on its summit. My friends at SennaSena declined
3 202
the responsibility of taking me into danger.
To the north of Morumbala we have a fine
Maganja view of the mountains of the Maganja, - they here
come close to the river and terminate in Morumbala.
Shíre Many of them are conical, and the Shire is
reported to flow amongst them and to come
on the SennaSena side of Morumbala, before
joining the ZambesiZambezi. All around to the South-
east, the country is flat, and covered with forest,
but near to SennaSena, a number of little abrupt
conical hills diversify the scenery. To the
west and north, the country is also flat forest,
which gives it a sombre appearance, but just
in the haze of the horizon South West by South,
there rises a mountain range equal in height to
Morumbala, and called Nyamónga. In a
clear day, another range beyond this may be seen,
which is GoronngózoGorongózo, once a station of the Jesuits.
Gorongózo is famed for its clear cold waters
and healthiness, and there are some inscriptions
engraved on large square slabs on the top
of the mountain which have probably been
the work of the Fathers. As this lies in the
Manica direction of a part between Manica and
SofálaSofála which has been conjectured to be
the Ophir of King Solomon, the idea that
first sprung up in my mind was that these
monuments might be more ancient than the
Portuguese, but on questioning some persons
who had seen them, I found that they were
in Roman characters, and did not deserve
a journey of six days to see them.

Manica lies three days north west
of Gorongóza, and is the best gold country
4 203
known in Eastern Africa. The only evidence
the Portuguese have of its being the ancient
Ophir, is, that at Sofala, its nearest port, pieces
of wrought gold have been dug up near the
fort, and in the gardens. They also report the
existence of hewn stones in the neighbourhood,
but these cannot have been abundant, for all
the stones of the fort of Sofala are said to
have been brought from Portugal. Natives
whom I have met in the country of Sekeletu,
from Manica, or MannioaManoa, as they call it,
state that there are several caves in the
country, and walls of hewn stone, which they
believe to have been made by their ancestors,
and there is, according to the Portuguese, a
small tribe of Arabs there, who have become
completely like the other natives. Two
Motirikwe rivers, the Motiríkwe and Sabía, or
Sabe, run through their country into the
sea. The Portuguese were driven out of the
country by the Landeens, but now talk of
reoccupying Manica.

Sorell The most pleasant sight I saw at
SennaSena, was the negroes of Senhor Isidore
building boats after the European model
without anyone to superintend their operations.
They had been instructed by a European
master, but now go into the forest, and cut
down the MotoundoMotondo trees, lay down the
keel, fit in the ribs, and make very neat
boats and launches, valued at from £20
to £100. Senhor Isidore had some of
them instructed also in carpentry at
Rio JaneiroRio de Janeiro, and they constructed for him
5 204
the handsomest house in Kilimane, the
wood-work being all of country trees, some of
which are capable of a fine polish and very
durable. A medical opinion having been asked
by the Commandant respecting a better site
for the village, which lying on the low bank
of the ZambesiZambezi is very unhealthy, I recommended
him to imitate the Jesuits, who had chosen
the high healthy mountain of Gorongozo,
and fix on a new site on Morumbala, which
is perfectly healthy, well watered and where
? the Shire is deep enough for the purpose of
navigation at its base; but the people of
SennaSena are not at present on friendly terms
with the inhabitants there. As the next
resource, I recommendedproposed removal to the
harbour of Mitilone, which is at one of the
mouths of the ZambesiZambezi,; and a much better
port than Kilimane,; and where if they must
have the fever, they would be in the way of
doing more good to themselves and the country
than they can do in their present situation.
Had the Portuguese proposed this territory
as a ^ real colony, this important point would not
have been left unoccupied; as it is, there is
not even a native village placed at the
entrance of this splendid river to shewshow the
way in.

On the 9th of May sixteen of ^ my men were
employed to carry government goods in canoes
up to Tete. They were much pleased at getting
this work. On the 11th the whole of the
inhabitants of SennaSena, with the Commandant,
accompanied us to the boats. A venerable
6 205
old man, son of a judge, said they were in
much sorrow on account of the miserable
state of decay into which they had sunk, and
in account of the insolent conduct of the
people of Kisaka, now in the village. We were
abundantly supplied with provisions by the
Commandant and Senhor Ferrão, and sailed
pleasantly down the broad river. About
thirty miles below SennaSena we passed the mouth
of the river Zangwe on our right, which
farther up goes by the name of Pungue;
and close to the end of a low range into which
Morumbala merges about five miles further
on our left, we crossed the mouth of the Shire,
which seemed to be about 200 yards broad -
A little further inland, there is another
rebel stockade, which was attacked by
Ensign Rebeiro, with three European soldiers,
and captured; They disarmed the rebels, and
threw the guns into the water. This Ensign
and MiranndaMiranda, volunteered to disperse the
people of Kisaka, who were riding roughshod
over the inhabitants of SennaSena, but the offer
was declined, the few real Portuguese fearing
the disloyal half-castes among whom they dwell.
Slavery and immorality have here done
their work; for nowhere else does the European
name stand at so low an ebb, andbut what
can be expected! Few Portuguese
women are ever taken to their colonies, and
here I did not observe that honorablehonourable
regard for their offspring which I noticed
in Angola. The son of a late Governor of
Tete was pointed out to me in the condition
7 206
and habit of a slave ^ I hope this may meet change.. There is no priest at
SennaSena, nor school, though there are ruins
of churches and convents.

Richards A few miles beyond the Shíre, we left the
hills entirely, and sailed between extensive
flats. The banks, seen in the distance, are
covered with trees. We slept on a large
inhabited island, and then came to the
entrance of the river Mútu. theThe point of
departure is called Mazáro, which means
"Mouth of the Mútu". The people who live
on the north are called Baróro and their
country Boróro. The whole of the right bank
is in subjection to the Landeens, who, it was
imagined, would levy a tribute upon us,
for this they are accustomed to do to passengers.
I regret that we did not meet them, for
though they are named Caffres, I am not
sure whether they are of the Zulu family
or of the Mashona. I should have liked
to have formed their acquaintance, and
learned what they really think of white
8 207
men. I understand from Sekwébu, and
Changamera's from one of the Changaméra’s people who lives
at Linyánti, and was present at the attack
on SennaSena, that they consider the whites as
a conquered tribe.

Mazaro The ZambesiZambezi at Mazáro is a magnificent
river, more than half a mile wide and
without islands. The opposite bank is
covered with forest of fine timber; but
the delta which begins here, is only an
immense flat, covered with high coarse
grass and reeds, with here and there a few
mango and cocoa-nut trees. This was the
point which was reached by the late
lamented Captain Parker, who fell at the
Sulina mouth of the Danube. I had a strong
desire to follow the ZambesiZambezi further, and
ascertain where this enormous body of
water found its way into the sea, but ^ on hearing
from the Portuguese that he had ascended
to this point, and had been highly pleased
with the capabilities of the river, I felt sure
that his valuable opinion must be in
possession of the Admiralty. On my arrival
in England I applied to Captain Washington
the Secretary of the Admiralty, and he
promptly furnished the document for
publication by the Royal Geographical
Society.

The river between Mazáro and the sea,
must therefore be judged of from the
testimony of the more competent to
decide on its merits than a mere landsman
like myself * [ insert

Rieg The conclusions of Captain Parker are strengthened
by those of Lieutenant A. H. Hoskins, who was on
the coast at the same time, and also visited this
spot. It ought to be remembered that the
testimony of these gentlemen is all the more
valuable, because they visited the river when the
water was at its lowest, ebb and the surface
of the ZambesiZambezi was not as it was now, on a
level with and flowing into the Mútue, but
16 feet beneath its bed. The Mútue at the
point of departure, was only 10 or 12 yards broad,
shallow, and filled with aquatic plants. Trees
and reeds along the bank overhang it so much,
that though we had brought canoes and a boat
from Tete, we were unable to enter the Mútue
inwith them, and left them at Mazáro. During
most of the year, this part of the Mútue is dry,
and we were even now obliged to carry all our
luggage by land for about 15 miles. As
Kilimanè is called in all the Portuguese
documents, the capital of the rivers of SennaSena,
it seemed strange to me that the capital
should be built at a point where there was
no direct water conveyance to the magnificent
river whose name it bore, and an inquiry, I
was informed that the whole of the Mútue was
larger in days of yore, and admitted of the free
passage of great launches all the year round
Tr/Transposition from Kilimane, but that now this part of the
Mútue had been filled up.

I was seized by a severe tertian fever
at Mazáro, but went along the right bank of the
Mútue to the N. N. E.North North East and E.East for about 15 miles.
We then found that it was navigable by a
river called the PanngázeiPangazi, which flowscomes into it
from the NNorth. Another river, flowing from the
same direction, called the Luáre, swells it
still more, and, last of all, the Likuáre, with
the tide, make up the river of Kilimane.
The Mútue at Mazáro is simply a connecting
link, such as is so often seen in Africa, and
neither its flow and stoppage affects the river
of Kilimane. The waters of the Pangázi
were quite clear compared with those of the
ZambesiZambezi. *

div.p:
My fever became excessively severe, in
consequence of travelling in the hot sun,
and the long grass blocking up the narrow
path, so as quite to exclude the air. The
pulse beat with amazing force, and felt
as if thumping against the crown of the head.
The stomach and spleen swelled enormously,
giving me for the first time, an appearance
which I had been disposed to laugh at among
the Portuguese. At Interra we met
Senhor AzeviedoAzevedo, a man who is well known
by all who ever visited Kilimane, and who
was presented with a gold chronometer watch
by the Admiralty, for his attentions to
English officers. He immediately tendered
his large sailing launch, which had a
house in the stern. This was greatly in
13 212
my favour, for it anchored in the middle of
the stream, and gave me some rest from the
mosquitoes, which in the whole of the delta are
something frightful. Sailing comfortably in this
commodious launch along the river of Kilimane,
we reached that townvillage on the 20th of May 1856,
which wanted only a few days of being 4 years
since I started from Cape Town. Here I was
received into the house of Colonel Galdino
Jose Nunes, one of the best men in the
country. I had been three years without
hearing from my family; letters having
frequently been sent, but somehow or
other, with but a single exception, they
never reached me. I received, however,
a letter from Admiral Trotter, conveying
information of their welfare, and some
newspapers which were indeed a treat.
H. M. B.Her Majesty's brig the "Frolic" had called to enquire
for me in the November previous, and
Captain Nolloth of that ship had most
considerately left for me a case of wine,
and his surgeon Dr. Walsh, divining what
I should need most, left an ounce of
quinine. These gifts made my heart
overflow. I had not tasted any liquor
whatever during the time I had been in
Africa, but when reduced ^ in Angola at LoandaLuanda
to extreme weakness, I found much
benefit from a little wine and took from
LoandaLuanda ^ thence one bottle of brandy in my medicine
chest, intending to use it if it were again
required, but the boy who carried it
whirled the box upside down, and smashed
14 213
the bottle, so I cannot give my testimony
either in favour of or against the brandy.

But my joy on reaching the East
Coast was sadly embittered by the news
Sedg that Commander MacLune of H. M.Her Majesty's Brigantine
"Dart" on coming in to Kilimane to pick me
up had, with Lieutenant Woodruffe and
five men, been lost on the bar. I never
felt more poignant sorrow. It seemed as
if it would have been easier for me to
have died for them, than that they should
all be cut off from the joys of life in
generously attempting to render me a
service. I would here acknowledge my deep
obligations to the Earl of Clarendon; and to
the Admiral at the Cape; and others for
the kind interest they manifested in my
safety; even the enquiries made were very
much to my advantage. I also refer
with feelings of gratitude to the Governor of
Mozambique for offering me a passage in athe
schooner ZambesiZambezi belonging to that province, and I shall
never forget the generous hospitality of Col:Colonel NineunesNunes
Nunes and his nephew, with whom I remained.
One of the discoveries I have made, is, that there
is a vast number of good people in the world,
and I do most devoutly tender my unfeigned
thanks to that Gracious One who mercifully
watched over me in every position, and influenced
the hearts of both black and white to regard
me with favour.
